description: Scene and chapter transition rules governing temporal flow, spatial movement, and narrative continuity

transition_principles.efficiency: Minimize transition prose; maximize forward momentum
transition_principles.clarity: Reader must always know when/where they are
transition_principles.purpose: Transitions should advance story, not just mark time
transition_principles.variety: Use different transition techniques to avoid monotony

temporal_transitions.description: Time passage must be clear and efficient

validations.name: time-passage-clarity
validations.description: Reader must always know how much time has passed between scenes

examples.violation: Scene ends at crime scene at night, next scene begins somewhere else with no time reference
examples.compliant: 'Three hours later, she sat in the precinct break room...' or 'The next morning brought...'

validations.validation_query: Does the reader know how much time elapsed between these scenes?

validations.name: time-jump-justification
validations.description: Large time jumps (>12 hours) should be earned by narrative need; summarize skipped events if relevant

examples.violation: Critical case day skipped with no explanation of investigative progress
examples.compliant: 'She spent the next two days running down dead-end leads. Witness alibis checked out. Forensics had nothing. On Thursday morning, her phone finally rang with something promising.'

validations.validation_query: What important events occurred during this time skip? Should reader know about them?

validations.name: investigation-time-realism
validations.description: Allow realistic time passage for investigative procedures: lab results, database searches, surveillance

examples.violation: DNA results come back in 10 minutes
examples.compliant: 'The DNA analysis would take 48 hours. She'd have to pursue other leads while waiting.' [Scene skip to 2 days later when results arrive]

validations.validation_query: Is this timeframe realistic for the investigative procedure described?

spatial_transitions.description: Location changes must be clear and efficient

validations.name: location-establishment
validations.description: New location must be established within first sentence or two of scene

examples.violation: Scene begins with dialogue; reader doesn't learn location for 2 paragraphs
examples.compliant: 'The medical examiner's office smelled like industrial disinfectant and death.' or 'She found him in the precinct garage, leaning against his cruiser.'

validations.validation_query: When does the reader learn where this scene takes place?

validations.name: travel-minimization
validations.description: Don't show routine travel unless it serves plot/character purpose; use hard cuts

examples.violation: 'She got in her car, started the engine, drove through traffic, parked, and entered the building.'
examples.compliant: Previous scene ends at precinct. Next scene opens: 'The witness lived in a fourth-floor walkup in Chelsea.' (travel implied, not shown)

validations.validation_query: What narrative purpose does showing this travel serve?

validations.name: meaningful-travel-scenes
validations.description: When showing travel, use it for character development, deduction, or plot advancement

examples.violation: Detailed description of commute with no story content
examples.compliant: During drive, detective reviews case file mentally, noticing pattern in victim locations; or partner conversation reveals relationship tension

validations.validation_query: What story function does this travel scene serve beyond moving character from A to B?

scene_to_scene_flow.description: Transitions between scenes must maintain momentum and clarity

validations.name: hard-cut-preference
validations.description: Use hard cuts (scene break line) instead of prose transitions when possible for pace

examples.violation: She left the crime scene, drove back to the precinct, parked in the garage, walked through the building, climbed the stairs, entered the bullpen, and sat at her desk.
examples.compliant: Scene ends at crime scene. ### Scene begins at desk in bullpen.

validations.validation_query: Could this transition be replaced with a scene break?

validations.name: transition-sentence-economy
validations.description: When prose transitions are needed, limit to 1-2 sentences maximum

examples.violation: Full paragraph describing journey from interview to next location
examples.compliant: 'Twenty minutes later, she pulled up to the warehouse district.' (single sentence, establishes time and location)

validations.validation_query: Can this transition be shortened to 1-2 sentences?

validations.name: momentum-preservation
validations.description: Scene transitions should maintain or increase narrative momentum, never deflate it

examples.violation: High-tension scene ends, transition dwells on mundane logistics, deflating tension
examples.compliant: High-tension scene ends on hook → brief transition maintaining urgency → next scene begins at similar or higher tension

validations.validation_query: Does this transition maintain the story's forward momentum?

chapter_transitions.description: Chapter breaks have specific transition requirements

validations.name: chapter-end-hooks
validations.description: Chapters must end on hooks that create urgency to continue reading

examples.violation: Chapter ends with character going to sleep after routine day
examples.compliant: Chapter ends with: revelation, cliffhanger, question, decision point, or escalation

validations.validation_query: Does this chapter ending create desire to keep reading?

validations.name: chapter-opening-grounding
validations.description: New chapters should quickly reorient reader to time, place, and situation

examples.violation: Chapter opens with abstract musing or dialogue with no context
examples.compliant: Opening sentence establishes when/where: 'The call came at 3 AM.' or 'She arrived at the precinct to find her captain waiting.'

validations.validation_query: Does chapter opening quickly establish context for reader?

validations.name: chapter-break-timing
validations.description: Place chapter breaks at natural story beats: after major scenes, before POV shifts, at time jumps

examples.violation: Chapter break mid-interrogation scene with no narrative justification
examples.compliant: Chapter ends after interrogation concludes (even on cliffhanger), new chapter begins next scene

validations.validation_query: Is this chapter break placed at a natural story beat?

pov_transitions.description: POV character changes require clear signaling

validations.name: pov-shift-markers
validations.description: POV changes must be marked with scene break (###) or chapter break, plus clear character establishment

examples.violation: POV shifts from detective to partner mid-scene with no break or warning
examples.compliant: Detective POV scene ends. ### [New scene] 'Marcus had seen that look before.' (immediately establishes new POV character by name and perspective)

validations.validation_query: Is the POV shift clearly marked with visual break and immediate new character establishment?

validations.name: pov-character-naming
validations.description: Establish new POV character's name in first sentence or two to avoid confusion

examples.violation: New POV begins with 'He walked into the room' with no indication of who 'he' is
examples.compliant: 'Marcus spotted her across the precinct bullpen.' (immediately identifies POV as Marcus)

validations.validation_query: Does the reader immediately know whose perspective they're reading?

act_transitions.description: Major story structure shifts need special handling

validations.name: act-break-chapter-alignment
validations.description: Major act breaks should align with chapter breaks for clear structure

examples.violation: Act 1 ends mid-chapter, Act 2 begins without clear marker
examples.compliant: Act 1 ends at chapter conclusion, Act 2 begins new chapter with changed situation

validations.validation_query: Does this major structural shift occur at a chapter boundary?

validations.name: act-two-midpoint-signaling
validations.description: Midpoint revelation should be clearly marked as major turning point

examples.violation: Midpoint revelation buried in middle of routine scene
examples.compliant: Midpoint revelation gets its own dramatic scene, possibly ends chapter with major hook

validations.validation_query: Is the story midpoint given appropriate structural emphasis?

investigation_continuity.description: Detective work creates specific transition challenges

validations.name: case-status-orientation
validations.description: After time jumps, briefly orient reader to current case status

examples.violation: Two days skip, reader unsure what investigative progress occurred
examples.compliant: 'Three days of interviews had yielded nothing. The case was going cold.' (establishes current status post-skip)

validations.validation_query: After this time jump, does reader know current case status?

validations.name: parallel-investigation-tracking
validations.description: When showing multiple investigation threads, clearly signal which thread is being followed

examples.violation: Rapid cutting between investigation threads with no clear markers
examples.compliant: Each thread gets clear scene breaks and opening orientation: 'While she interviewed the witness, her partner was running down the financial angle.'

validations.validation_query: Can reader easily track which investigation thread they're currently following?

magical_world_transitions.description: Urban fantasy may include transitions to magical spaces or altered states

validations.name: reality-shift-clarity
validations.description: Transitions into magical spaces/visions/altered states must be immediately clear to reader

examples.violation: Character slips into vision, reader confused about whether events are real
examples.compliant: 'The world tilted. Suddenly she wasn't in the precinct anymore.' or 'The vision hit like a freight train—'

validations.validation_query: Does the reader know they're entering a magical/altered state?

validations.name: reality-return-marking
validations.description: Transitions back to mundane reality must be equally clear

examples.violation: Vision ends ambiguously, unclear when character returns to normal perception
examples.compliant: 'She gasped, back in her body, gripping the desk. Her partner was staring.' (clear return to normal reality)

validations.validation_query: Is the return to mundane reality clearly marked?

agent_integration.bailey: Monitor transitions during drafting; ensure clarity and efficiency
agent_integration.edna: Validate transition pacing; identify unnecessary transitions to cut
agent_integration.tessa: Check temporal and spatial continuity across transitions
agent_integration.miranda: Review chapter break placement and hook effectiveness
